data.title: Make ysort work recursively
data.body:
This adds a recusion depth option to the YSort node which allows nodes from multiple sub-nodes to be drawn in y-order. This is especially helpful when you want to use multiple tilemaps which should be y-sorted together (which isn't possible at the moment).

To achieve this, I had to rewrite a bit of the canvas item rendering code. It is now a little bit more complicated and every canvas item uses a bit more memory, even if YSort isn't being used at all. I ran some tests though (Bunnymark) with and without the modification and it seems that there is no noticable difference for me. 

I don't know if anyone  but me wants this feature at all, but I decided to make a PR anyway because why not. As I said, it doesn't have any noticable impact for me, and if it's fine for anyone else it could as well be merged. So test and discuss please.

data.title: CollisionPolygon2D doesn't snap properly to grid
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux 64 - 2.2 branch

**Issue description:**
When moving a CollisionPolygon2D around with snap enabled, it never snaps to the grid. It will always create a small offset as soon as it is move by the mouse. This doesn't happen with any other node.


**Steps to reproduce:**
Create new scene. Create root node. Create PhysicsBody. Create CollisionPolygon2D as a child of it. Make sure everything is set to position (0,0). Enable snap or pixel snap mode. Draw a polygon with one point at the origin of the scene. Select the polygon node with the mosue and try to move it by one grid step. It will immediately get off by something and will then move by the set step size. 

EDIT:
It seems that this is caused by the snap point of the polygon being always the top left corner of the outer box around the polygon, which is automatically adjusted when the polygon is drawn (and scales with its size). This is bad, it should instead snap to the origin of the polygon node.

data.title: Z-Ordering Issue in 3D materials with Alpha
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
LinuxMint - Godot 2.1.1

**Issue description:**
There is a z-ordering error when you have two 3D materials with Alpha ("Use Alpha" option on) intersecting each other. This happens with Sprite3D's and meshes.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Any 2 intersecting 3D sprites with Alpha should make this Issue happen, with any combination of depth-draw option.

**Link to minimal example project:**
Here is the video of the Issue happening: https://youtu.be/zQgYQPi7PZ0
The project used: [z-ordering-issue.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/721008/z-ordering-issue.zip)

data.title: Label node size does not auto-update through code
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 10 64-bit, Godot on Steam

**Issue description:**
If you change the text field on a Label, it will update the margins, and update the length with `get_size().x` on the Label. However, these do not update automatically when setting the text field through GDScript.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a Label. Write some text in it. Delete the text, or leave it.
Adjust the Label's text field using `set_text("something")` in a script.
Use `get_size().x` or `get_margin(MARGIN_RIGHT)` to retrieve the text's X size.
It will retrieve the same size as it had when the text was first entered in the Inspector, and not the new size.

To get the new updated size, you have to force Godot to update its Inspector through code. This can be done by creating `var update = get_size()`, and then `set_size(update)`, which forces it to re-check.

data.title: Editor Zoom strange behavior
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64-bit Professional, AMD 64, 24 GB Ram


**Issue description:**
Several times now as I am editing a scene I cannot zoom in on objects.  I scroll the mouse wheel and when it stops zooming the object is still 1-2 inches square in the center of my monitor.  I also tried using the ALT + drag Middle Mouse button and that still doesn't work.  

What is weird is if I open 2-window layout the second window works fine.  Of course I cannot force window 1 to the view position of window 2.

Did I get the editor in some weird mode I need to exit from? 
I cannot find any docs on this.  

I have built Godot successfully locally so I am more than willing to help out if there is indeed a bug.

Thanks

data.title: Raycast to Area not adhering to Layer/Mask
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1.1 STABLE
3.0-alpha

**Issue description:**
Raycast nodes have a Layer Mask property to filter which CollisionObjects are picked up by the cast. The Layer/Mask works properly for PhysicsBody objects such as KinematicBody, but not for Area. Regardless of which Layer/Mask is specified for Area or RayCast, the RayCast will detect a collision with the Area.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create node `Area`
 - Create child `CollisionShape` - Set to any desired shape
- Create node `RayCast`
 - Set Layer Mask to exclude Layer(s) used by Area
- Observe that `RayCast` node's `is_colliding()` returns `True`


**Link to minimal example project:**

This ZIP contains 2.1.1-Compatible and 3.0-alpha-Compatible scenes.

[test_proj.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/719905/test_proj.zip)

data.title: GDScript allows name a variable the same as a function parameter
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 (probably also affects 3.0)


**Issue description:**
A variable inside a function can be named like a parameter for that function with no error. I expect that in an inner scope, but not at the main scope of the function.


**Steps to reproduce:**
This script:
```
func function(param):
    var param # This should produce an error
    if true:
        var param # Here I think it's OK to allow it
                  # since you are shadowing the parameter
                  # inside an inner scope at your own risk
```

I'm not sure why this was commented out, but it seems to work fine, at least in the 2.1 branch. :)

The blame shows it was disabled in its initial checkin, so my guess is it was a mistake.

This should fix #7582.

data.title: Ability to group node icons in Scene dock to drop-down menu.
data.body:
I like to have layout in which I have two docks next to each other on the right side of the window.
But this layout means these docks need to be thin. And when Scene dock is too thin and nodes in it have too many icons their names are not visible.

![scene](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8977194/22150975/43eb8aee-df1c-11e6-8c82-72eeb8d57b6d.png) 

So my feature request is a mode in which these icons would be in some kind of drop-down menu. It doesn't have to be default behavior, but it might be a nice feature switchable in the engine settings.

data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10, Intel i7, Godot 2.1 from official website.

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Everytime I run scene, the game works, but then I go back to edit few things, the bone/skeleton of a character is gone. So basically I have to do the skeleton all over again.

**Steps to reproduce:**
I have [body scene] which contains the skeleton of body (without head). I instance it in a [character-name scene], which contains full body like the head. And then I instance [character-name scene] in [map-scene].

So everytime I run the [map-scene], the skeleton in [body scene] gets resetted.

**Link to minimal example project:**
It's an adult game...
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->:

data.title: Python-like list unpacking
data.body:
One of my favorite things in python is unpacking list to values.

```python
a, b, c = [1,2,3]
# a == 1
# b == 2
# c == 3

first, *rest = [1,2,3]
# first == 1
# rest == [ 2, 3 ]

for a,b in [[1,2], [3,4]]:
    # 0: a == 1, b == 2
    # 1: a == 3, b == 4
    pass
```

I have a lot of GDScript code that looks ugly and woody without this feature. It makes me sad. I won't be sad.

I want to know your opinion about this feature and try to implement this if it proves popular.

data.title: made _ a special token in GDScript
data.body:
As discussed in #7575 the `_` was made a new token and connot be used as a regular identifier anymore. Names using `_` are still valid. Only the single `_` is special.

GDScripts pattern matching was modified to support this new token.

data.title: TCP/UDP listen bind to address and bugfixes
data.body:
As discussed in #6992 this PR implements socket binding to specific interface.

- `IP_Address` now has `is_valid` method to check if it's a valid IP address (not an empty struct).
- `IP_Address` now parses `*` wildcard and owns a method `is_wildcard` (used to refer to dual stack binding).
  - `0.0.0.0` and `::` are of course specific IP binding as per standard
- `listen` function no longer takes a list of accepted host but only one `bind_address` (you can't bind on multiple interfaces selectively, either you choose one or all of them). Default = `*`
- `listen` uses the socket type of the bind address, or dual stack in case of wildcard (falling back to IPv4 on OpenBSD since this platform does not support dual stacking).
- `connect` and `set_send_address` always resolves IP using `AF_UNSPEC` (preferred interface for given hostname) and creates a socket of the given address type (in case of UDP only if not already active).
- all references to `set_ip_type` as been removed since testing specific IP type can be done by proper binding and manually calling resolve_hostname with specified type.

During the testing I also found some bugs, and odd behaviors which I fixed here's a summary (see details in commit log):
- UDP poll was trying to recv even if the socket was closed
- Trying to write to a connecting TCP stream could result in deadlock since the polling from connecting to connected status was done in blocking mode.
- UDP did not initialize and reset the receive buffer properly when used in "client mode" (no listen)

data.title: Add known issues to 2.1 docs
data.body:
Thera are some bugs/inconsistencies in how angle functions works (`atan2`, `angle_to_point`, etc.) that won't be fixed until 3.0 for compatibility.

The thing is that I find sometimes digging among issues to recall which ones were affected.

What I am proposing is adding a _Known Issues_ section to the 2.1 docs with a summary about this so it gets documented and easily checkable.

data.title: Shared texture path setting missing in Project Settings.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot v2.1.1.stable.official
Ubuntu Gnome 16.04 - x86_64
NVIDIA GeForce GTX570 - Driver version: 367.57

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The "Import 3D scene" window lists an option to import textures to a shared path in the project tree, but there is no option present in the Project Settings window to specify this path anywhere.

See [this Q&A post](https://godotengine.org/qa/11553/how-the-shared-texture-import-option-the-import-scene-window) for further info.
And [this bit of documentation](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/tutorials/3d/importing_3d_scenes.html#source-target-paths) that describes this feature.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open the "Import 3D scene" window, set the "Target Texture Folder" to the "Shared" option, and then notice that there is no way to specify this path in the Project Settings. (Either that or I'm overlooking something, would really appreciate it if someone could explain how this works.)

data.title: `match` pattern and using `_` as a wildcard
data.body:
#6593 
I've done some shallow research on the subject. A few cases were mentioned of `_` being used as a wildcard being the idiomatic way to do a wildcard match.

**Haskell** wildcard patterns use `_` for wildcards[[1]](https://www.haskell.org/tutorial/patterns.html). However, a valid Haskell variable name must begin with a lowercase[[2]](https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Haskell/Variables_and_functions#cite_note-1).
**Scala** also uses `_` as a wildcard[[1]](http://docs.scala-lang.org/tutorials/tour/pattern-matching.html). Scala uses the `_` for more than just pattern matching[[2]](http://docs.scala-lang.org/style/naming-conventions.html).
**Elm** uses `_` in pattern matching as a wildcard that is not going to be used. It uses a lowercase 'tags' to match anything if you want to use the value[[1]](https://learnxinyminutes.com/docs/elm/) 
**Racket**, as far as I can tell, uses `_` as a placeholder variable name, but I couldn't find any reference to it being a symbol especially restricted to wildcards or wildcards being restricted to using `_`[[1]](https://docs.racket-lang.org/guide/match.html)
**F#**, uses `_` as a wildcard pattern[[1]](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/pattern-matching), 
**OCaml** uses `_` as a wildcard pattern[[1]](http://xahlee.info/ocaml/pattern_matching.html)
**Rust** uses `_` as a wildcard pattern[[1]](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/patterns.html)

Two options, make `_` an invalid variable name or use something else for wildcards in the GDscript's `match` pattern.

There's also the chance that whatever we use as a wildcard here could be used in other places in the future. I'd prefer it if we used `*` since it could also be used if GDscript ever got argument list *like in python* (I'm not aware of whether this is implemented or will ever be)

I want to start a discussion around this, because I believe this can decide the future direction of the language.

data.title: Fix Spatial::is_visible and editor calls to CanvasItem/Spatial::is_visible
data.body:
It looks like there was some unfinished work which removed `is_hidden` for `CanvasItem` and `Spatial` to leave only `is_visible`.

- While the method was removed, editor calls to it were not.
- `is_visible` in `Spatial` returned `!data.visible`, quite self explaining what I fixed here.
- There seems to have been some `_set_visible_` method in `Spatial`, but only `set_visible` exists by now.

I also removed unnecessary negation in the visibility boolean checks in the editor code.

This fixes hiden and showing thus nodes in the editor.

data.title: Allow saving arrays as resource
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Tested on 2.1.1 stable

**Issue description**
Resources like shapes and curves can be saved as files in the editor (with the save icon) but built in types like Arrays, which are often used like those resources (to make polygons and things like that), can't be saved, making it complicated to copy the data in a simple way.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a node that uses an Array or export an Array variable on a script, create a new array if needed and go to edit the array in the inspector, the save button is disabled.

PS: the load button is enabled ~~but I'm not sure if it works because arrays can't be saved~~ and may break things because it can load anything (only tried with a mesh library resource)...

data.title: Cannot undo "Clear" action from script editors context menu
data.body:
Godot 2.1.1 stable
Ubuntu 16.04

Description:
Pressing the "Clear" option in the script editors context menu causes the script to be cleared, as expected, but it isn't possible to undo the clear (Ctrl+z or "Undo" in the context menu)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a script
2. Add some lines of awesome code
3. Right click and press "Clear"
4. Press undo as you want your lines of awesome code back
5. Start crying because your code is now gone


I'm guessing it is just "undo_redo->add_do_method()" and "undo_redo->add_undo_method()" that should be done where the clear method is located. Please correct me if I'm wrong.
